She will use half of her loan to purchase more groceries for sale and the rest to buy an ox to support her in the farm work. (S. was not available at that day, so her husband is shown instead in the picture).

loans.use: To purchase more groceries for sale and to buy an ox to support her in the farm work

loans.name: Renchin

texts.en:
R. is 47 years old and lives with her three children in the Zavkhan province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her two younger children attend the university.

R. operates a meat inspection laboratory in her town. She got permission from the government and began to operate her business in 1998. She examines samples of all the meat products in the local markets for quality and cleanliness. For each sample she takes, she is paid about 50 cents. She is proud that she provides a valuable service to her community by protecting her neighbors from potentially dangerous food.

She says, “I want to continue to pay the tuition fees for my children and I want them to be educated young adults with a great passion and enthusiasm for life.”

She is planning to expand her laboratory and to buy new tools in order to increase the quality of her service. She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan in order to purchase new, high-tech tools for her meat inspection business.

loans.use: To purchase new, high-tech tools for her meat examination business

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy G. is from the village of Tigdok, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 28 years old, is married, and has one infant child. Joy owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,600 PHP a month. In 2009, Joy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase piglets to raise and sell. Joy is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Glenda

texts.en:
Glenda, of Brgy. Mabini, Valladolid, Negros Occidentala, is a 51-year-old woman who prays to the Lord to give her strength, good health and long life to continue her business and help her family. Her husband is a farmer who plants different kinds of vegetables and manages their small rice farm. The couple has four adult children between 24 and 31 years old. Glenda strives hard in her business to not only support their household needs but also to be financially independent.

Glenda started her business in 2002 when she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to borrow capital to put up a general store adjacent to her house. As soon as her first loan was granted, she bought a variety of items and products to sell, and any extra income from the store is always used to buy more goods to sell. As her loans have continued, she has also helped her husband by buying fertilizers for his vegetables and rice farm. Glenda also sells her husband's vegetable harvest in the local market and in the neighboring villages. Her business is going well, earning an average income of Php 10,000 per month.

Her previous loan of Php 10,000, fully repaid without delay, was used as additional working capital for her general store. Because of her good credit performance, she can borrow a larger amount, and this time around she is borrowing Php 15,000 for her 14th cycle loan to be utilized as revolving working capital for her general store and to purchase additional fertilizer for their vegetable and rice farm. The income from this loan will be used for house repairs.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy new stocks for her general store and fertilizer for the vegetable and rice farm

loans.name: Rosa Isela

texts.es:
La señora Rosa Isela desde hace 5 años inicio su negocio de Ropa usada de todas tallas y colores. En este momento ella quiere capital para cambiar la ropa de la temporada pasada, ya que en este invierno es muy helado el clima y los clientes le solicitan prendas más gruesas para pasar esta temporada invernal. También quiere prevenirse por la época navideña donde ella obtiene más ganancias y es así como ella compra todo lo de la cena de nochebuena para convivir con sus seres queridos.
Su esposo es una persona trabajadora que la apoya con los gastos del hogar el se dedica a la venta de dulces de leche de todos sabores.
texts.en:
Sra. Rosa started a business five years ago selling used clothing of all sizes and colors. At the moment, she seeks capital to change out the clothing from the previous season. This winter the weather is very cold and customers are requesting thicker clothing so that they can endure this period. She also wants to be prepared for the Christmas season, which is the time she generates the most revenue. This is how she earns the money she needs to buy everything for Christmas Eve dinner and spending time with loved ones.

Her husband is a hardworking person who helps with the household expenses. He sells dulce de leche (a sweet sauce similar to caramel) in all flavors.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for the winter season

loans.name: Adedeji

texts.en:
Adedeji is 39 years old and married with 3 children. His wife is a tailor and she supports her home.

Adedeji loves shoes and that is why he makes and sells shoes. He sells shoes at wholesale and retail prices to his customers. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He hopes to own a shoe factory in the future. He hopes for a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more leather to make more shoes to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more leather to make more shoes to sell

loans.name: Veneranda

texts.en:
Veneranda A. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 55 years old. Veneranda is a widow and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Veneranda owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Veneranda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $88 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Veneranda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Veneranda has successfully repaid a previous loan from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. 

Veneranda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to sustain her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Kakh Boland Group

texts.en:
This is Kakh Boland group which is made up of two female members. These two members would like to receive money for their husbands.

Shila is the group leader and she wants to receive money for her husband who has a cart which he uses to sell kitchen utensils. With the loan he wants to purchase more materials which are in demand so as to progress his business.

The second member of this group is Mah Gul who wants to receive the loan for her husband who has a cosmetics shop. With the loan he would like to buy good quality cosmetics to attract more clients.

Both members would like to thank Kiva lenders a lot.

loans.use: To buy more kitchen utensils for her husband's business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy building materials and supplies.

loans.name: Arturo Celso

texts.es:
Arturo tiene 37 años de edad, es casado y tiene dos hijos de 10 y 7 años de edad, vive junto a su familia en el distrito de Paiján, perteneciente a la provincia de Ascope, en la región La Libertad, ubicada a dos horas y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Tiene instalada una bodega en su vivienda desde hace dos años. En ella ofrece a sus clientes todo tipo de abarrotes y artículos de primera necesidad. Instaló su bodega poco a poco con los ahorros que percibía de sus trabajos como obrero eventual, la bodega fue creciendo gracias a su esfuerzo y al buen trato que ofrecia a sus clientes, y ahora que sus hijos ya estudian y el ya tiene un trabajo estable mas como vigilante, esta bodega se ha convertido en una fuente importante de apoyo a la economía familiar.

Arturo desea invertir en la ampliación de su negocio con la compra de abarrotes y bebidas, por ello se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

El es un hombre empeñoso y que ha sabido progresar de acuerdo a sus posibilidades. Ya ha trabajado anteriormente con nuestra Institución y demostrado ser un cliente puntual y responsable al momento de asumir sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Arturo is 37, married and has 2 children, ages 10 and 7. He lives with his family in the Paiján district in Ascope province, La Libertad region, about two and a half hours from the city of Chiclayo, capital of the Lambayeque province. He has had a store in his house for the last two years. In it he sells all kinds of groceries and basic necessities to his customers. He built the store little by little with the savings that he had from his work as a temporary laborer. The store grew thanks to his effort and to his good service to the customers. Now that his children are in school and that he has a regular job as a guard, the store has become an important source of income for the family. Arturo wants to invest in enlarging his business by buying groceries and drinks. That is why he is asking Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 2000 new soles to help him with this goal. He is a hard-working man that has learned how to get ahead the best way he can. He has worked with our institution in the past and shown himself to be punctual and responsible when he has to make his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy groceries and drinks to enlarge his store

loans.name: Abdulato

texts.ru: Назаров Абдулато проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 40 лет. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Абдулато занимается торговлей. Он продает запасные части автомашины. Этим видом бизнеса занимается уже 8 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Abdulato N. lives in the Vahdat district. He is 40 years old, married and has 2 children. His wife is a homemaker. Abdulato is involved in retail sales. He sells automotive spare parts and has been involved in this business for 8 years. He is requesting the loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Hajji Juma

texts.en:
Hajji Juma K. is a successful businessman. He is thirty-five years old and has a retail shop located in Kasubi, Kampala, which he has been operating for over four years.

Hajji Juma is using the loan to purchase items like sugar, posho (maize flour), cooking oil, salt, soap, etc., to expand his business.

Hajji Juma is a hardworking businessman whose future dream is to set up a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To purchase items like sugar, posho, cooking oil, salt, soap, etc., to expand his business

loans.name: Maria Ofelia

texts.es: Maria Ofelia tiene 54 años, su actividad económica es la venta y destace de cerdos. Hace más de 6 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que sus inicios se dan porque Maria no era una mujer muy humilde y la responsabilidad de sus hijos contribuyeron a que ella buscara un medio de medio de ingreso para su hogar, así fue que poco a poco ella fue creciendo con esta actividad. Por lo que ahora solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo y así comprar cerdos. Su deseo es que sus hijos en futuro se hagan cargo del negocio.
texts.en:
Maria Ofelia is 54 years old and manages a business selling and butchering pigs. When she started her business more than six years ago, she was a very humble woman and took responsibility for her children. They, in turn, contributed toward half of the household income. Little by little, her business grew over time.

She is now requesting a loan to use as operating capital to buy pigs. Maria hopes that her children will take over the business in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital to buy pigs

loans.name: Jiguisèmè Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Jiguisèmè sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et  3 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames à KAMALEN SIRAKORO un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur troisième  prêt solidaire. Les prêts précédents se sont bien dénoués. 
Les membres de son groupe  font la vente d’ignames, de fruits, de friperie et  de condiments alimentaires. 
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, MARIAM T. compte acheter, 2 balles de friperie. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso ville. Elle revend au marché de Kamalen Sirakoro, dans les foires des villages avoisinants  Kamalen Sirakoro et à domicile, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle compte avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et  pouvoir aménager un point de vente.
texts.en:
The members of the Jiguisèmè group are married women, on average 30 years old with three children. Mostly they live in monogamous families in Kamalen Sirakoro, a village in the commune of Sikasso in Mali's 3rd administrative region. They work with Soro Yiriwaso, a microfinance institution, to meet their customers' needs, and are currently repaying their third loan. They sell yams, fruit, used clothing and condiments. With their new loan Mariam T. plans on buying two bales of used clothing from the big market in Sikasso city for resale in the market in Kamalen Sirakoro, in neighboring villages, and from home, for cash and on credit to both men and women customers. She hopes for an average monthly income of 17,500 FCFA, some to be saved, some for her family's needs, and some to be invested in her business. With this increased capital, she hopes better to serve her customers and to be able to operate from a single location.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy used clothing

loans.name: Nekpa Group

texts.en: Abdul Fatah is a member of the Nekpa guoup. He lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and has four children. He is a hard-working man and the only one in the family responsible for all the household expenses. He has a business selling mobile phone cards. He needs this loan to purchase more cards so he can expand his business and give his children a better life. He is confident that he will repay his loan on time and will join for the other cycle loan soon.

loans.use: To purchase mobile phone cards

loans.name: United We Stand Group

texts.en:
Kaibeh A., shown holding the sign in the photo, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called United We Stand. She is 38 years old, married and has two children, 10 and 16 years old respectively. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to poverty. 

Since one year ago, she has been selling soft drinks and juices at Redlight Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She says customers get attracted to her business because she talks to them in a friendly manner.

She plans to use her 8,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 40,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more crates of soft drinks and juices. She describes herself as a very peaceful person.

Her dream is to grow her business, educate her children and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more crates of soft drinks and juices.

loans.name: La Fe 6,7 Group

texts.en:
Dioselina is the coordinator of her group La Fe (The Faith), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, where the sugarcane harvest dominates the economy and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her common-law husband and their two children.

Dioselina is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and expanded her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a colmado (general store) by purchasing rice, flour and sugar to sell. She will use the profits to provide for her children's basic needs, including purchasing notebooks. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to buy rice, flour and sugar

loans.name: La Caridad 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Felicita is the coordinator of her group La Caridad 1 & 2 (The Charity). She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and two children. 

Felicita is excited to be taking her sixth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and expanded her business. She plans to use this loan to expand her fried food stand where she sells hot dogs, chicken, plantain and meats, and extend her products to shoes and cosmetics. She will use the profits to invest in other products like jewelry, to buy her children school supplies and to change her family's  lifestyle. In the meantime she plans to continue enjoying making business. She is always doing a work activity and after she got her first loan and started with her fried food stand, with every loan she is thinking to expand her business.

Felicita's story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally, many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in in San Pedro de Macoris, a city famous for baseball players and sugar cane industries, the main economic activity is a free trading zone, a cement factory, and others. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and unreliable electricity.

loans.use: To expand her business where she sells fried food, shoes and cosmetics.

loans.name: Agnès

texts.fr: K. D. Agnès est née en 1956 et est mariée à AWISSOU Etienne, un jardinier. Le couple a quatre enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Il y a environs cinq ans que la famille habite Cocotomey dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi. Agnès subvient ensemble avec son mari aux besoins de la famille grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. N'ayant pas fréquenté l'école, Agnès vend des friperies et des éponges de toilette de façon ambulante, ce qui lui permet de faire face à ses besoins. Agnès achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Agnès exerce cette activité depuis quatre ans et a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Dans le but d'agrandir son activité et d'accroître sa clientèle, Agnès sollicite un autre crédit afin de se faire plus de revenu.
texts.en:
Agnès K. D. was born in 1956 and is married to Etienne Awissou, a gardener. The couple have four children, some of whom are in school. The family have lived for about five years in Cocotomey in the community of Abomey Calavi. Together with her husband, Agnès helps pays the family expenses thanks to her business income. Not having gone to school, she sells secondhand clothing and cosmetic sponges on foot, which allows her to meet her needs. Agnès buys her products in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has been engaged in this business for the last four years and has already obtained two loans through ALIDé, both of which she has repaid in full. With the goal of growing her business and gaining more customers, Agnès is requesting another loan to increase her income.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a bale of secondhand clothing.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia V. is from the village of Brgy. Aggub, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 48 years old. Delia is widowed and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Delia owns and operates a business venture in the food sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fish to the local community. Delia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,600 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Delia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Delia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Delia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Bonface

texts.en:
Bonface is 29 years old, married and a father of three. He is a mechanic by profession. He repairs vehicles in a busy environment and has three employees. He has operated the business for three years.  

Bonface joined Faulu Kenya under the Ukilyo group. Since then, he has been able to employ casual workers in his business. He has previously serviced two loans from Faulu Kenya. Currently, he is requesting for a loan of 80,000 KES to buy paint and vehicle spare parts. He hopes to expand his business so as to make more profit. In five years, he wants to have his own business premises instead of renting.

loans.use: To buy paint and vehicle spare parts

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon A. is a married woman who lives in Purok Peacock, Brgy. Cubay Masville, La Carlota City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:  a coffee shop, a general store and a food vending business. Her husband, Mamerto A. Sr., who is 50 years old, works as a carpenter to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have six children who are 17 to 28 years old. 

Corazon joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Corazon has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 18,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 9000 PHP, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 11th loan, she is borrowing 18,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy more foodstuffs to sell in her coffee shop and her general store to sustain her businesses and continue to save for future home repairs and expansion of her business. Corazon A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at Kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Maria Gricelda

texts.es:
María tiene 33 años y se dedica a la venta D. productos lácteos y destazo D. ganado, resiD. en San Antonio departamento D. San Miguel, vive con su esposo y sus cuatro hijos,  tres D. ellos son niñas, D. las edades 17, 15, 8 y 3 años D. edad; Ellos son personas humildes y su único ingreso lo reciben a través D. la venta D. lácteos y carne D. res.
Su negocio aun es pequeño, ella con la ayuda D. su esposo destazan reces y venden su carne en la casa o en algunos casos salen a vender a los pueblos cercanos, el destazo lo realizan 2 veces por semana.
Ella está solicitando un préstamo pues quieren ampliar su negocio y comprar cerdos para el destazo y vender su carne;  también quieren comprar quesos, mantequilla y otros derivados D. la leche, todo esto para ofrecer a sus clientes y contar siempre con su preferencia.
Este préstamo será una gran ayuda para esta familia ya que diversificaran sus productos a la venta y aumentaran sus ingresos pues cubrirán con más demanda D. producto.
La Proyección D. María es comercializar por mayor, aumentar sus ventas y sus clientes, ofrecer a sus hijos una mejor vida con acceso a la educación para que estos se preparen y opten por una vida diferente con nuevas oportunidades D. desarrollo.
texts.en:
María is thirty three years old and works selling dairy products and meat. She lives in San Antonio, which is in the department of San Miguel. She lives with her husband and their 4 children, 3 of whom are girls. They are 17, 15, 8, and 3 years old. They are humble people, and they get their only income from the sale of dairy products and beef.
Her business is small. With the help of her husband, she butchers cattle and sells the meat from her home or in nearby towns. They butcher twice a week. 
She is requesting a loan to grow her business and buy pigs to butcher so she can sell the meat. She also wants to buy cheese, butter, and other dairy products to sell to her clients and comply with their wishes. 
This loan will be a big help to this family as it will let them diversify the products that they sell and increase their income and meet the demands for these products. 
For the future, María wants to sell wholesale, increase her sales and clients, and offer her children a better life with access to education so that they will be prepared and choose a different life with new opportunities for development.

loans.use: To buy cheese, butter, and pigs to sell

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana M. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 56 years old and single. To make a living, Ana plants and harvests rice to sell. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately $175 a month for these activities.

In 2005, Ana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Ana is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 8th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: San José Mi Group

texts.es:
Las integrantes que conforman el  comité “San José Mi” actualmente se encuentran iniciando con gran entusiasmo el 1° ciclo dentro del programa comité de mujeres y son señoras vecinas del barrio, todas las Señoras invertirán el dinero recibido en la compra de insumos y más mercaderías para la posterior venta.
Este grupo que inicia el primer ciclo son de la Zona de Ayolas, todas las Señoras son del mismo barrio, cada una de las Señoras tienen actividades diferentes y han unido sus esfuerzos para trabajar conjuntamente y así lograr progresar, no solo monetariamente, sino en forma personal, gracias a las capacitaciones que irán desarrollando en el transcurso de los ciclos.
Una de las integrantes es la señora Maria quien se dedica a la atención de su salón de belleza donde realiza trabajos de peluquería como cortes, tintas, peinados, y otros, además realiza trabajo de manicura y pedicura. 
Comenta que le va muy bien con su salón y tiene una cliente formado que solicitan sus servicios semanalmente, y está muy contenta con el grupo y espera aprender mucho.
texts.en:
The members who make up the “San José Mi” committee are currently starting their first loan cycle within the women's committee program with great enthusiasm.  The women are all neighbors and they all use the money they receive to buy supplies and merchandise which they then sell.

The members of this group, which is starting its first loan cycle, are from the Ayolas area.  All the women are from the same neighborhood and each one carries out different business activities.  They have united their efforts to work together and thereby make progress not only financially but also on a personal level thanks to the training sessions that are developed over the course of the loan cycles.

One of the members is María who runs a beauty salon where she performs hairdressing services such as haircuts, colors and hairdos as well as manicures and pedicures.

María comments that her salon is doing very well and she has a regular client base who request her services weekly.  She is very happy with this group and she is hoping to learn a lot.

loans.use: Purchase of hairdressing products such as shampoo, conditioners, oils, etc.

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie I. is from the village of Brgy. Inaban, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 42 years old. Elsie is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Elsie owns & operates a business raising pigs for breeding. Elsie has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elsie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Elsie is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Elsie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

location.town: Brgy. Inaban, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Belencita

texts.en:
Belencita L. is from Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years old. Belencita is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Belencita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & junk foods in the local community. Belencita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Belencita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Belencita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Belencita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Belencita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Anastasiya

texts.en:
Anastasiya is married and has a small son. She sells all kinds of souvenirs at an open market in Novaya Kahovka. Anastasiya started this business nine years ago because she needed to support her family. Today her business is going well. Anastasiya enjoys selling souvenirs very much and would like to develop her business further. 

Anastasiya is requesting a loan of 12,000 grivnas to increase the assortment of souvenirs to sell during this Christmas season. Anastasiya is hoping to receive additional income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of souvenirs

loans.name: Mirian

texts.es:
Mirian es socia del Banco Comunal “3 de Mayo II” del distrito Puno,  provincia de Puno y departamento de Puno, tiene 20 años, de estado civil soltera, la señorita en la actualidad sigue estudiando.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela  Ramos desde hace 04 meses, su  préstamo inicial fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, el cual invirtió en su negocio de producción de mana.

Solicitara un nuevo crédito de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, con el cual comprará fideos, trigo, azúcar y maíz para su producción de mana, trabaja junto con sus padres.

Su visión en el negocio es independizarse, tener su propia maquinaria y poner una tienda.

Lo que le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro y lo que gana.
texts.en:
Mirian is a member of the May 3rd II Communal Bank in the District, Province, and Department of Puno. She is 20 years old and single. This young lady is currently continuing her education.

She has been working with Manuela Ramos for four months. Her first loan was for 300 PEN and invested in her business of making “mana” (a type of candy dough).

Mirian is requesting a new loan in the amount of 500 PEN in order to buy pasta, wheat, sugar, and corn used in making “mana”. She and her parents work together.

Her vision with her business is to become independent, have her own machinery, and establish a store. What she enjoys most about her Communal Bank are the savings and the interest she earns.

loans.use: Purchase pasta, wheat, sugar, and corn

loans.name: Foryirra Group

texts.en:
Yeabu T. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Yeabu was born in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone about thirty-five years ago. She is married to a businessman and the couple has four children – two in primary school and two in secondary school.

For four years now, Yeabu has been selling palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), rice, groundnuts, pepper etc. This is first loan that Yeabu and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. Yeabu will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to expand her business, she will buy the above mentioned items at wholesale to add to her current ones. 

(Included in the right of the photo is loan officer Mohamed L. Tarawalie, handing over the loan to the clients)

loans.use: Buys palm-oil, rice, groundnuts, pepper etc. at wholesale to add to her business

loans.name: Koun

texts.en: Koun P. sells a few wares in front of her home. She sells items like soft drinks, sweets for kids, and some cooking supplies. Her husband works as a local farmer and earns an income of around US$3 each day to share with Koun P. the responsibility for providing for the family’s living expenses. Koun P. is blessed with a lovely child, who still lives under her care. Recently, the stock of some of Koun P.’s items has been exhausted; she wants to restock and is requesting a loan to replenish her inventory to continue selling. Note: Koun P. and her young child appear in the photo.

loans.use: To replenish her inventory to continue selling

loans.name: Stephen Muiruri

texts.en:
Stephen has operated his retail shop in Naivasha town for the last three years. He is 27 years old and married to Mary Wanjiru--together they have one child.

He was introduced to KADET LTD  by his friend. This will be Stephen's first loan. He plans to use the loan to buy sugar, rice and flour in bulk. He will resell them in small quantities.

In the future, Stephen hopes to grow his retail shop into a wholesale business.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice and flour in bulk to resell in small quantities.

loans.name: Florencia

texts.es: La señora Florencia se dedica a la venta D. productos D. primera necesidad en su domicilio, hace 2 años, tiene una tienda D. barrio donD. le va muy bien por la buena atención que le brinda a su clientes y también por la variedad D. productos que ofrece  y con esta actividad sustenta a su familia, su esposo se fue a España a buscar mejores oportunidades para la familia  y envía cada mes remesas para su sustento y también para la construcción D. sus casita,  la señora Florencia se hizo cargo D. su nieta ya que su hija  viajó a Argentina también en busca D. mejores oportunidades.  En la actualidad tiene un hijo que está a su cargo que se encuentra estudiando. Vive en casa propia hace 10 años, es una persona muy responsable y trabajadora con ganas D. superación, esta agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado en la otorgación del crédito.
texts.en: Florencia sells basic necessity products from her house. For 2 years she has had a neighborhood store and it is going very well for her because of the great service she gives her customers and also the variety of products she offers. She supports her family with this activity. Her husband went to Spain to seek better opportunities for the family and he sends remittances every month for support and also to build their little house. Florencia took over the care of her granddaughter since her daughter travelled to Argentina, also in search of better opportunities. At present, she has a son under her care who is in school.  She has lives in her own house for 10 years. She is a very responsible and hardworking person who wants to get ahead. She is grateful to the institution for the support it has offered in giving the loan.

loans.use: To buy groceries and improvements for the business

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys O. is aged 35 and a single mother of three children, Mary, Elizabeth and Jack, who are all in primary level of schooling. Gladys runs a cafe business as her primary business located at Babadogo, and her business of 4 years generates a monthly profit of Kshs 10,000.

She joined KADET LTD and this is her first loan which she intends to use to buy new deep-frying pans for preparing "mandazi"s (snacks made from wheat flour, deep fried in oil), tables for displaying the cooked mandazis and tablespoons.  She plans to use the profits to venture into other projects which can add extra profit. 

Gladys hopes to successfully run her business and be financially stable. She describes herself as a hard-working businessperson who is always committed to her work so as to please her customers.

loans.use: To buy new deep-frying pans for preparing "mandazi"s, tables for displaying the cooked mandazis and tablespoons.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal “RICHARY RUNA”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

El socio es el Sr. Daniel; el tiene 59 años de edad y es viudo y tiene 5 hijos; el socio alterna sus actividades diarias con su negocio, él socio cuenta con un carro que realiza el servicio de mudanza el trabaja de lunes a domingo por el día ,su horario puede variar de acuerdo a la actividad que pueda realizar durante el día, el socio es una persona bien responsable y dedicado a sus hijos aun que ya sean adultos sus hijos el igual sigue apoyándolos en lo que puede, él socio desea continuar de esta forma seguir trabajando para su familia.

El socio solicita el préstamo para realizar el mantenimiento de su carro y comprar algunos accesorios que le hacen falta. 

El socio está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos
texts.en:
The associate belongs to the ” RICHARY RUNA” communal bank.  The bank is located in the district of Cusco, which belongs to the province of Cusco and department of Cusco. 

The associate is Señor Daniel.  He is 59 years of age, widowed and has 5 children.  The associate alternates his daily activities with his business.  The associate relies on a car that he uses for a moving service which he works from Monday to Sunday during the day.  His schedule can vary according to the activity that he can carry out during the day.  The associate is a very responsible person and dedicated to his children even though they are already adults.  He continues supporting them in that which he is able.  The associate desires to continue in this way working for his family.  

The associate requests the loan to carry out maintenance of his car and to buy some accessories that he needs.  

The associate is happy for the loan and he promises to comply with the payment schedule.

loans.use: to maintain his car and buy some accessories that it lacks.

loans.name: Heidy Milena

texts.es: Heidi y es una joven muy emprendedora que vive con sus padres y hermanos  en uno de los barrios mas alegres y autóctonos de la ciudad de Barranquilla y desde allí se dedica a la fabricación de almohadas, colchas y cojines; Heidy pertenece a una familia muy unida y aprendió de su padre esta actividad  desde que tenia 12 años; ella recuerda como en ese momento empezó  su proceso de comprensión del emprendimiento y el aprendizaje de este digno oficio. Su principal satisfacción es cortar, preparar y ensamblar piezas, mediante la costura, para lograr productos de un gran acabado. De esta manera Heidy consigue olvidarse de las pocas posibilidades de empleos empresariales que existen y se dedica a producir para obtener sus ingresos y esto la hace estar muy feliz, disfrutando de lo que le gusta y especialmente por estar unidad cada día mas a su familia. Este es su primer financiamiento con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo con el cual logrará mejorar la cubierta de su negocio,  para evitar el reflejo del caliente sol y la impredecible lluvia; así mismo comprará tela y esponja  en un mayor volumen, porque requiere elaborar sus delicados productos. Así mientras continua trabajando y  su margen de rentabilidad no es inferior del 30%, su sueño principal se centra en tener una sala de exhibición con todos los productos que fabrican, pensando en un futuro no muy lejano tener su vivienda de dos plantas, para independizar el espacio familiar del productivo.
texts.en: Heidy is a very entrepreneurial young woman who lives with her parents and siblings in one of the most cheerful and indigenous neighborhoods in the city of Barranquilla.  From there, she makes pillows, bedspreads, and cushions.  Heidy belongs to a very united family, and she learned this activity from her father from the time she was 12 years old.  She remembers how at that time she began the process of understanding the enterprise and learning this noble work.  Her principal satisfaction is cutting, preparing, and assembling pieces, through sewing, in order to achieve high-quality products.  In this way, Heidy has been able to forget about the few opportunities that exist for jobs in business.  She produces in order to earn her income, and this makes her very happy.  She enjoys doing something she likes, especially because she is becoming closer with her family every day.  This is her first loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, and she will use it to improve her business' roof in order to avoid the reflection of the hot sun and the unpredictable rain.  She will also buy cloth and foam in greater volume, because she needs it to make her delicate products.  While she continues working in this way and her profit margin is not less than 30%, her principal dream centers around having a showroom with all the products she makes.  Thinking of a future that is not so far away, she wants her house to have two stories, in order to separate family space from work space.

loans.use: to improve her business' roof and to buy cloth and foam in greater volume

loans.name: Korn's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. K., born in 1967, was selected to be the village bank president by the other members of this eight-member village bank loan. She and her husband, Mr. Seng. who was born in 1968, are farmers who own 3-hectare plot of land upon which they grow rice and corn for their family living. Mrs. K. would like to request a loan to buy gasoline and fertilizers to support her crops. She and her husband also earn additional income by fishing.

This couple has five children, two of whom are seamstresses in the garment factories, while the others are students who also help in their parents' businesses.

loans.use: to buy gasoline and fertilizers to support her crops.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita L. is from the village of Sto. Niño. She is 39 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Margarita owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fruits in the local community. Margarita has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month.

In 2011, Margarita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Margarita is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fruits to sell. This loan will be Margarita's first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishepeople, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fruits to sell

loans.name: Merina

texts.en:
Merina lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala in Uganda.  She is widowed and has 6 children, 2 of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (grandchildren).    

Merina has a retail shop business which she has been running for over 10 years. She works 7 days out of every week.   She also generates additional income by renting rooms.

Merina has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and jerry cans of cooking oil.   The main business challenges for Merina include transportation, thieves, and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations are to own a delivery van, to start selling wholesale, and to educate her children up to university.   

Merina lives in a home that she owns.  She has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more sugar, salt, soap, and cooking oil to resell

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia is married and has three children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Alicia is 48 years old and has one child who is in school. 

Alicia has a sari-sari (variety) store business in the Philippines. Alicia requested a 20,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy more stock for her store. 

Alicia has been in this business for five years. In the future, Alicia would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: buy more stock for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Ric Marcial

texts.en:
Ric Marcial is 42 years old and lives in Lapasan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental Philippines. He is a married man and a father of two school-age children.

Ric Marcial has a retail store that sells basic food items like, rice, corn, oil, milk and sugar. He has been engaged in this business for more than two years with a monthly income of PHP 10,000. Ric Marcial requested a loan of PHP 20,000 from GDMPC to purchase assorted food products to sell.

Ric Marcial is a new member of GDMPC. In the future, he hopes to expand his business and allow customers to have a greater choice.

loans.use: To purchase assorted food products to sell.

loans.name: Charina

texts.en: Charina, 24 years old, married, and the mother of one child, is a very hardworking entrepreneur who has operated a clothing sales business in the Philippines for the past four years. Charina is requesting a PHP 22,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase more blouses, pants, and jewelry to sell. In the future, she would like to save enough money to build a house for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more blouses, pants, and jewelry to sell.

loans.name: Bryan

texts.es:
Bryan es un hombre sencillo y pertenece a una comunidad de la zona Sur de Costa Rica, ubicada en Concepción de Pilas, Puntarenas. La economía local está basada en actividades agropecuarias, donde destaca la siembra de tubérculos, café, maíz, frijoles y ganadería.
El necesita un préstamo por el monto de ₡500.000 (quinientos mil colones),  ya que se dedica a la agricultura por el tipo de zona en el que vive donde la mayoria trabaja en este campo. Bryan necesita este dinero para la compra de semilla de tubérculos, para así ofrecer gran variedad de producto a sus clientes en el momento de la cosecha.Y ademas Bryan destaca que su objetivo es aumentar sus ingresos económicos por medio de esta actividad agrícola, para así poder solventar todo gasto que se presente en su nucleo familiar para brindarles una mejor calidad de vida.
El pertenece a la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de La Danta S.A.
texts.en:
Bryan is a simple man who belongs to a community in the southern zone of Costa Rica, located in Concepción de Pilas, Puntarenas. The local economy is based in agricultural activities, especially raising tubers, coffee, corn, beans, and cattle.

He needs a loan in the amount of  ₡500,000 (five hundred thousand colones), as he works in the type of agriculture that is typical for his region, as do most of the people who live in the area. Bryan needs this money to purchase seeds for tubers so that he can offer a greater variety of products to his customers at harvest time. Furthermore, Bryan says that his goal is to increase his income through farming, so that he can meet all of the expenses faced by his immediate family, in order to offer them a better quality of life.

He belongs to the "La Danta S.A." communal bank.

loans.use: to buy seeds for tubers

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.en:
Jeanne is a 40-year-old Rwandan entrepreneur with four children between the ages of 4 and 14 years old  Her husband raises animals and she sells fruit.

She has been running her fruit business for the past 15 years, and she requires this loan so that she can purchase 100 bunches of bananas, 80 pineapples, and 4 sacks of avocados that she will sell for a profit.

loans.use: to buy fruit for sale.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is from the village Gvara, Kobuleti District, Seaside of Georgia. He is 41 years old and married. He lives with his wife Tea, 14-year-old son, and 7-year-old daughter. His children go to school.

David owns a small grocery shop in the village and works there. Tea leads the agricultural activities of the family. In particular, they have tangerine and nut trees and sell harvested products in the local open market. 

As it is now tourist season on the seaside, David has requested credit for increasing the assortment of the products in his store, in order to attract as many customers as possible. It will positively impact the family’s income. David and Tea will use the profit they receive to purchase new goods for their children, especially for the new season at school.

loans.use: to purchase products to increase the stock at his grocery store.

loans.name: Conception

texts.en:
Conception is requesting a loan amount of 15,000 PHP to buy a weighing scale, ice, and new Styrofoam that she needs for her business selling fish. With this, she hopes to earn a higher income so that she can send all of her children to school. Regardless of financial hardship, she is not giving up. She strives to provide for all the needs of her children.

She is 41 years old and married. She has three children. One of them stopped attending school due to financial difficulty. Her income from selling fish is not enough. She needs to increase her 6,000 PHP monthly income in order to sufficiently support her family. She is thankful to have a motorcycle that she uses to sell fish around her village and in nearby villages.

loans.use: to buy a weighing scale, ice, and new Styrofoam

loans.name: Edelberto

texts.en:
Edelberto is married with one child. He is 29 years old and lives in Poblacion, Salug, Zamboanga del Norte.

Edelberto sells charcoal to earn a living and has had this business for two years. Each month, he earns 20,000 PHP selling charcoal. He has requested a loan of 30,000 PHP to purchase fifty sacks of charcoal.

Edelberto became a member of PMPC this year.  In the future, Edelberto hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase fifty sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Cacilda

texts.pt:
Nasceu no distrito de Boane, provincia de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, casada e mãe de 3 filhos que todos frequentam a escola. Fez a 11ª classe devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e sustenta mais 2 sobrinhos que vivem com ela. 

Nunca saiu da sua terra natal, é professora ha mais de 18 anos e tem um salario de 2.500.00mt, por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e poupa algum na sua conta bancaria.
Ja teve emprestimos em outros bancos(BIM) e conseguiu pagar sem dificuldades, conheceu a Hluvuku atravez de amigas que tambem saõ clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu quarto emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 12.000.00mt, com qual pretende comprar material de construcao DE UMA CASA (areia, pedra, ferro, cimento e outros) para dar continuidade a sua obra. O primeiro emprestimo foi de:10.000.00m, para a obra.
Pretende solicitar mais valor para concluir a sua casa e dar continuidade com os estudos, irá solicitar mais emprestimos a Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Caclida was born in the district of Boane, in the province of Maputo in southern Mozambique. She is married and the mother of three children, who go to school. She only went to school through the eleventh grade because of her family's economic circumstances. She lives in her own home with her family, and also supports two nephews who lives with them.
She's never left Boane. She's been a teacher for more than 18 years and earns about 2,500 meticals a month. He uses his salary to pay for household expenses and also saves a little in a bank account.She's had loans from other banks (BIM) to build her house, which she paid off without any problems. She learned about Hluvuku from friends who are also clients of the institution. This is her fourth loan with Hluvuku, in the amount of 12,000 meticals, which she will use to buy construction materials (sand, stone, iron, cement, etc.) to continue work on her house. Her first loan was in the amount of 10,000 meticals for the construction.She hopes to ask for further loans from Hluvuku to finish her house and continue her studies.

loans.use: to buy construction materials (sand, stone, iron, cement, etc.).

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
La señorita Mercedes es estudiante, tiene 25 años de edad, está cursando la carrera de Licenciatura en enfermería en la Universidad Privada del Guaira.
Comenta además que es funcionaria contratada de la Secretaria Nacional de la Vivienda y el Hábitat. Mercedes con mucho esfuerzo está logrando cubrir los gastos de su estudio como la matricula, materiales didácticos y otros. Su sueño es terminar la carrera, ser una enfermera  profesional y servir a su comunidad.
Con este crédito que solicita ella va a pagar las cuotas que le quedan de este año y pagar derechos de examen. La misma agradece a Fundación Paraguaya y Kiva por el apoyo ofrecido porque gracias a eso ella va a poder continuar estudiando.
texts.en:
Mercedes is a 25-year-old student enrolled in a program in The Private University of Guaira to become a licensed nurse.

She mentions also that she works as a civil servant for the Secretaria Nacional de la Vivienda y el Hábitat (Ministry of Housing and Habitat).  With a great deal of effort, Mercedes is managing to cover her educational expenses such as registration fees, educational materials, and other expenses.  

Her dream is to finish her course, become a professional nurse and serve her community.

With this loan she will pay her current fees for this school year and pay her examination fees.  She wishes to thank Fundación Paraguaya and Kiva for offering their support, since thanks to this loan she will be able to continue studying.

loans.use: to cover exam fees and other educational fees.

loans.name: Toiata

texts.en:
Toiata is 54 years old and married with five children. She provides general alteration and tailoring services to the local community. She has 10 years of experience in this business. Toiata needs a loan of WST $2700 to purchase additional fabric and materials. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 800 talas or US $333 per week) to improve the general living conditions of her family.

In 2001, Toiata joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Toiata's ninth loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabric and materials.

loans.name: Association Dental 16 Group

texts.fr: L'association" Dental 16 " est composée de cinq femmes toutes mariées.Elles exercent dan l'artisanat notamment la teinture. Elles achètent des tissus divers et font la teinture pour les revendre à leurs clients.Le chef du groupe ( qui tient la fiche d'autorisation)est une femme très dynamique qui a subi une formation de trois mois en teinture.Chaque mois, elle place ses produits à domicile et se fait payer au bout de deux mois.Elle est mère de trois enfants qui vont tous à l'école.Son activité lui permet de prendre en charge ses propres besoins ainsi que les frais de scolarité de ses enfants et leur habillement.Pour satisfaire la forte demande à l'approche de la fete de "Tabaski", l'association sollicite auprès de l'UIMCEC un pret de 250000f pour acheter du tissus et des produits de teinture.L'association ambitionne de s'implanter au marché central pour toucher le maximum de clients.
texts.en: The group “Dental 16” is made up of 5 married women.  They  all work in the business of tinting fabric.  They buy various types of fabric, dye them, and sell them to their customers.  The leader of the group (who is holding the permit) is a very dynamic woman who has had three months of training in fabric dyeing.  Each month, she takes her products home and is paid at the end of two months.  She is the mother of three children who all go to school.   Her work allows her to take care of her own needs as well as schooling and clothing for her children.   To meet the high demand at the arrival of the festival of Tabaski, the loan group is requesting from l’UIMCEC  a loan of 250000 F to buy fabric and tinting products.   The group hopes to set up shop at the central market in order to reach the maximum number of customers.

loans.use: to buy fabric and tinting products.

loans.name: Liliana

texts.es: Liliana tiene 26 años, es una mujer trabajadora y emprendedora. Vive en compañía de pareja y de su único hijo, a quien quiere mucho. Juntos habitan en su casa propia, que lograron comprar hace pocos años, con mucho esfuerzo. La actividad que realiza, es la costura, actividad que aprendió de muy joven gracias a su madre. Paralelamente también se dedica en la venta de comida, negocio que lo hace por las tardes, para lo cual dispone de una mesa que instala en el frontis de su casa, ahí atiende a todos sus clientes. Tiene tres meses vendiendo comida y hasa el momento le va bien, ya que ha logrado captar regualar clientela. Lo que le gusta de su actividad es el poder tener un ingreso económico, de esa manera apoya a su pareja con los gastos de su hogar, además se siente productiva e independiente. Considera rentable, éste último negocio, pues le genera más ganancias, mientras que en tiempo libre le da lugar a la costura. Su plan es seguir con la venta de comida e intensificarse. Este sería el primer crédito con la institución MFP, se siente muy contenta con el grupo que conforma, pues todos son personas responsables y solidarias. Con el monto solicitado, lo invertirá en la compra de ingredientes para la preparación de comida, como: arroz, aceites, fideos, pollos; asimismo comprará telas e hijos.
texts.en:
Liliana, 26, is a hardworking, enterprising woman.  She lives with her spouse and only son who she lives very much.  They live together in their own house that they managed to buy a few years ago with much effort.

Her main activity is sewing, a skill she learned when still very young thanks to her mother.  At the same time she also sells food, a business she carries out in the evenings.  To do so, she has a table set up in her front yard where she tends to her customers.  She’s been selling food for three months and to date has been doing well since she’s managed to acquire a regular clientele.

What she likes about her activity is being able to have income to help her spouse with household expenses.  Besides, she feels productive and independent.  She considers the latter business to be profitable because it generates more income while she can do the sewing in her free time.  Her plan is to continue with the food sales and intensify them.

This will be her first loan with MFP.  She feels very happy with the group she belongs to because they are all responsible and mutually supportive people.  She will use the requested amount to buy ingredients to prepare her dishes: rice, oil, noodles, chickens.  She will also buy fabric and thread.

loans.use: to buy rice, oil, noodles and chickens as well as fabric and thread.

loans.name: Thanh

texts.en:
Thanh is 46 years old. She lives in Cho town, Yen Phong, Bac Ninh. She has two children. She has a general store. She sells groceries. She has had this job for 10 years. 

She has a monthly income of about 6.000.000 Vietnam dong (VND). This is the 6th time she has had a loan from SEDA. The last time she borrowed 8.288.000 VND and repaid this loan punctually. This time she wants to borrow 9.632.000 VND to buy foodstuffs, drinks, dairy products and other things for her general store.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs, drinks, dairy products and other things for her general store.

loans.name: Malu A Group

texts.en:
Grace is the facilitator of the Malu A group. Grace and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Grace and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. 

The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Grace takes care of nine children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough to secure food for her family and to have additional maize profits to send her children to school. With income from her maize sales, Grace will save for the future and invest in livestock rearing as savings for future use.

In 2012, the members of Malu A group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

The photograph shows Grace with her group members and standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Retchie

texts.en:
Retchie is 40 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has one child.
 
Retchie has a shop that sells electronic loads from several networks like Globe and Smart. She has had this business for five years. 

She requested a loan for PHP 6,000 to buy additional stocks of electronic loads.

Retchie has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Retchie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of electronic loads.

loans.name: Xuyen

texts.en: Xuyen is a 41-year-old woman with three daughters. She lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City and makes money by selling soft drinks. For the past five years, she has run a soft drink stall to cover her family's daily living expenses and her children's education fees. The business is going smoothly and she would like a loan to buy many kinds of beverages to provide to her customers. She hopes this will increase her income, help her to improve her living conditions and allow her to set aside some savings.

loans.use: to buy many kinds of beverages to provide to her customers.

loans.name: Cesar

texts.es:
César es de la ciudad de Paraguarí, tiene 32 años está casado con la Sra. Cinthia, tienen 1 hijo de 9 años de edad, el cual está en la primaria. Ellos comentan que su hijo es la razón de lucha de ellos.
César  es carpintero desde hace más de 7 años, empieza sus actividades diarias a muy tempranas horas y regresa muy tarde por la noche. El comenta que tiene buena clientela ya que siempre hace muy buenos trabajos y eso le ayuda. Una de las metas de César es aumentar su taller y de esa forma poder recibir más pedidos. Además de eso nos comenta que comenzó recientemente con la actividad de venta de bebidas heladas y productos de primera necesidad, en lo que ya le esta yendo muy bien también.
El solicita el crédito para la compra de bebidas, con lo cual podrá abastecer su nuevo local, y de esa forma cumplir con sus clientes.
texts.en:
César is from the city of Paraguarí.  He is 32 years old and married—he and his wife Cinthia have one son, who is 9 years old and is in primary school.  César and Cinthia say that their son is their reason for striving onward.

César has been a carpenter for more than 7 years.  He starts his daily activities very early in the morning and comes back home late at night.  He says that he has a good clientele, and he does very good work and that helps.  One of César’s goals is to expand his workshop so that he can receive more orders.  In addition, he recently started selling frozen beverages and staple products, and that activity is also going well.

César is asking for the loan so he can purchase beverages.  This will allow him to stock his new business and thus meet the needs of his customers.

loans.use: to purchase beverages to sell.

loans.name: Happiness Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the "Happiness " group from Koindu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of 500,000 Leone (SLL) each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. 

Doris is the leader of this group. The thirty-five-year-old is married to a farmer and the couple have four children together. Doris has been a businesswoman for seventeen years now; she sells slippers. With her share of this loan, she will buy a large quantity of shoes to add to her business. 

Also included in the photo is loan officer Edward, handing over the loan to the borrowers.

loans.use: to buy a large quantity of shoes to add to her business

loans.name: Theany

texts.en:
Theany, 27, is widowed. She resides with her mother and one child in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. 

She has been running a grocery store for over three years and is successful in her career. Her mother helps her run the business. 

In order to improve her family economy, Theany is requesting for a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more groceries to sell to generate more income. In the future, she would like to expand her business, renew her house and send her child to a good school.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Limamou

texts.en:
This loan will be shared by the seven members of the Propaf group, represented by Limamou S.. Their village, Ker Gu Mag, is located in the arid grasslands of central Senegal, where people depend on a mixture of subsistence agriculture and cash cropping for their livelihoods. The loan funds will be used to purchase stocks of local grains – principally millet and corn – during the harvest season when supply is abundant and prices are low. The grains will then be processed and sold at retail as flour and animal feed throughout the year.

Background

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group. Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, which provide the rural poor throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities. Repayment rates within these groups are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members. However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income. This has prevented the traditional associations from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities. Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance (SEM) works with our partner organization CRESP to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Millet and Corn Retail

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana T. lives in a High School community in Dodowa in the Greater Accra Region of Ghana. She sells fried yams and fish to the students. She travels a long distance from her place to a farming community to buy the yams in bulk. Because of the cost of transporting the yams to her place, which she cannot afford, she stopped going for the yams. She is seeking a loan of $900 from Kiva to enable her get back to her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her business by buying more stock.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.es:
ENGLISH

Rosalinda is married and has nine children, but she lives alone with her husband because all her children are married. Her husband works as a refrigerator repairman from their home. Rosalinda began her business 10 years ago and she does not have any employees. She began the business because she needed to help her husband with the family expenses. Her husband’s income varied from month to month, and with nine children to provide for and educate, it was necessary for her to work. Rosalinda started her business with a small capital of US $50.00, with which this she bought notebooks and pencils, and this was how she began her stationary business. She has added diverse products to her business, at the request of her customers, and would like to continue with the business.

Rosalinda is requesting a loan in the amount of $925.00 to purchase gifts and others new merchandise, which will give her a better variety of products to offer in her business. She offers to repay the loan in 6 months. She and her husband thank you for your support, which will allow her to continue with her business.

SPANISH

Rosalinda esta casada y tiene 9 hijos, pero ella vive sola con su esposo, ya que todos están casados. Su esposo trabaja como técnico en refrigeración y lo tiene establecido en su domicilio, ella no tiene empleados e inició hace 10 años con su negocio, ya que tenía que ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de la familia por que sus ingresos no eran fijos y con tantos hijos a los cuales mantener, brindarles sus estudios y alimentación, era necesario trabajar. Rosalinda inició con un pequeño capital de US $ 50, con los que adquirió libretas y lápices y fue así con eso como empezó su negocio de papelería, el cual ha seguido agregándole diversos productos a pedido de sus clientes y desea continuar con su negocio.

Rosalinda esta solicitando un préstamo por la cantidad de US $ 925 para poder comprar regalos y novedades los que harán tener más surtido para su negocio y ofrece pagar el préstamo en 6 meses. Ella y su esposo te agradecen mucho por apoyarla a continuar con su negocio.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Natig

texts.en:
Natig R. is 40 years old and married with 2 children. He is from Azerbaijan in the Armenian conflict territory, Gubadli region, situated in the western part of Azerbaijan. Natig began his business 8 years ago. He is the only income-earner for his family. In 1999 he opened an area for car repairing in Sumgayit city.

In 2004 Natig borrowed $300 from Normicro and expanded his business, bought necessary tools and equipments for his repair area, increased the number of his clients, and considerably increased his income. The second time, he borrowed $600 and bought new apparatuses and other car repair necessities.

Now, he needs to borrow $800 to expand his repair area, make necessary changes, and to repair his workplace. He thinks that this expansion will improve the living conditions of his family. He will repay the loan within 14 months.

loans.use: To expand repair area, to make necessary changes, and to repair workplace

loans.name: Sallay

texts.en: Sallay is married with four children.  Sallay sells Potatoes, Cassava and occasionally, cooked food. Sallay is 33 years old and  contributes to  some of the family expenses.  Her husband is also a petty trader in Magburaka town.  She said her main concern is her children’s school requirements.  She would like to expand and diversify her business, and is therefore requesting a loan of $175.

loans.use: Expand her business by purchasing more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
For 15 years now, Victoria has been traveling her city's streets on her small tricycle cart selling a wide variety of seasonal fruits and vegetables; right now she is diligently selling delicious and nutritious corn, a primary product in Peru, for which there is a great demand at this time. Victoria is an industrious businesswoman and mother of three who works tirelessly along with her husband, Francisco, who works in a mine located far from home. The very reason he works is to be able to offer his little ones an education and a decent life. Victoria wants to buy even more products so that by selling them she can generate greater revenue and then be able to save and finish refurbishing her home. She was very devoted to building this house along with her life-long partner, her husband. To make her plans a reality, Victoria is asking for a loan that she promises to repay in six months. Right now they are eagerly awaiting your response.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.
